panels.description: The I/O throughput on this OSS.

targets.alias: I/O Throughput
targets.query: SELECT "sum" FROM "cqm_ost_stats_bytes-fs_name-ost_index" WHERE "fs_name" = '$fs_name' AND "optype" = 'write' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY "ost_index"

panels.title: I/O Throughput

panels.description: The write throughput on this OSS.

targets.alias: Write Throughput
targets.query: SELECT "sum" FROM "cqm_ost_stats_bytes-fs_name-optype-ost_index" WHERE "fs_name" = '$fs_name' AND "optype" = 'write' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY "ost_index"

panels.title: Write Throughput

panels.description: The read throughput on this OSS.

targets.alias: Read Throughput
targets.query: SELECT "sum" FROM "cqm_ost_stats_bytes-fs_name-optype-ost_index" WHERE "fs_name" = '$fs_name' AND "optype" = 'write' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY "ost_index"

panels.title: Read Throughput

panels.description: Active requests are the requests that is being actively handled by  OSS, not including the requests that are waiting in the queue.  If the number of active requests is smaller than PTLRPC thread number minus two (one for incoming  request handling and the other for incoming high priority request handling), it generally means the thread number should be enough. The value shown in this graph is the minimum number during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Minimum Number of Active Requests

panels.title: Minimum Number of Active Requests

panels.description: Active requests are the requests that is being actively handled by  OSS, not including the requests that are waiting in the queue.  If the number of active requests is smaller than PTLRPC thread number minus two (one for incoming  request handling and the other for incoming high priority request handling), it generally means the thread number should be enough. The value shown in this graph is the average number during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Average Number of Active Requests

panels.title: Average Number of Active Requests

panels.description: Active requests are the requests that is being actively handled by  OSS, not including the requests that are waiting in the queue. If the number of active requests is smaller than PTLRPC thread number minus two (one for incoming  request handling and the other for incoming high priority request handling), it generally means the thread number should be enough. The value shown in this graph is the maximum number during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Maximum Number of Active Requests

panels.title: Maximum Number of Active Requests

panels.description: Incoming requests are the requests that waiting on preprocessing. A request is not incoming request any more when its proprocessing begins. And after preprocessing, the requests will be put into processing queue.  The value shown in this graph is the minimum number of incoming requests during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Minimum Number of Incoming Requests

panels.title: Minimum Number of Incoming Requests

panels.description: The wait time of a request is the time interval between its arrival time and the time when it starts to be handled. The value shown in this graph is the maximum wait time of the requests during the last collect interval.

panels.description: When a client sends a request, it has a timeout deadline for the reply. The timeout value of a service is an adaptive value negotiated between server and client during run-time. The value shown in this graph is the minimum timeout of the OST service during the last collect interval.

panels.description: When a request arrives, one request buffer will be used. When number of available request buffers is under low water, more buffers are needed to avoid performance bottleneck. The value shown in this graph is the minimum number during the last collect interval.

panels.description: Active requests are the requests that is being actively handled by OSS, not including the requests that are waiting in the queue.   If the number of active requests is smaller than PTLRPC thread number minus two (one for incoming  request handling and the other for incoming high priority request handling), it generally means the thread number should be enough. Create requests include object creation requests and statfs requests. The value shown in this graph is the minimum number during the last collect interval.

panels.description: The wait time of a request is the time interval between its arrival time and the time when it starts to be handled.  The value shown in this graph is the maximum wait time of the requests during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Maximum Wait Time of LDLM Callback Requests

panels.title: Maximum Wait Time of LDLM Callback Requests

rows.title: Wait Time of LDLM Callback Requests

panels.description: When a client sends a request, it has a timeout deadline for the reply. The timeout value of a service is an adaptive value negotiated between server and client during run-time. The value shown in this graph is the minimum timeout of the service during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Minimum Adaptive Timeout Value of LDLM Callback Service

panels.title: Minimum Adaptive Timeout Value of LDLM Callback Service

panels.description: When a client sends a request, it has a timeout deadline for the reply. The timeout value of a service is an adaptive value negotiated between server and client during run-time. The value shown in this graph is the average timeout of the service during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Average Adaptive Timeout Value of LDLM Callback Service

panels.title: Average Adaptive Timeout Value of LDLM Callback Service

panels.description: When a client sends a request, it has a timeout deadline for the reply. The timeout value of a service is an adaptive value negotiated between server and client during run-time. The value shown in this graph is the maximum timeout of the service during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Maximum Adaptive Timeout Value of LDLM Callback Service

panels.title: Maximum Adaptive Timeout Value of LDLM Callback Service

rows.title: Adaptive Timeout Value of LDLM Callback Service

panels.description: When a request arrives, one request buffer will be used. When number of available request buffers is under low water, more buffers are needed to avoid performance bottleneck. The value shown in this graph is the minimum number during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Minimum Number of Available LDLM Callback Request Buffers

panels.title: Minimum Number of Available LDLM Callback Request Buffers

panels.description: When a request arrives, one request buffer will be used. When number of available request buffers is under low water, more buffers are needed to avoid performance bottleneck. The value shown in this graph is the average number during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Average Number of Available LDLM Callback Request Buffers

panels.title: Average Number of Available LDLM Callback Request Buffers

panels.description: When a request arrives, one request buffer will be used. When number of available request buffers is under low water, more buffers are needed to avoid performance bottleneck. The value shown in this graph is the maximum number during the last collect interval.

targets.alias: Maximum Number of Available LDLM Callback Request Buffers

panels.title: Maximum Number of Available LDLM Callback Request Buffers

rows.title: Number of Available LDLM Canceld Request Buffers

list.label: Filesystem Name
list.name: fs_name
list.query: SHOW TAG VALUES FROM "ost_kbytesinfo_free" WITH KEY = fs_name

list.label: OSS
list.name: oss
list.query: SHOW TAG VALUES FROM "ost_kbytesinfo_free" WITH KEY = fqdn WHERE "fs_name" = '$fs_name'
